faq:
Q: I irrigated still the sensor is showing dry.
A: Ask user when he irrigated. It usually takes 12 hours to reach the water till sensor. If the sensor is not dropping even after 12 hours, it can be due to one of the following reasons :
Water is not reaching properly till the sensor , this can be due to drip blocked , or slope in the land or dripper outlets far away from the sensor. Ask user to check if drip is fine and  dripper is within the range of sensor. 
The sensor can be very old , more than two years , in this case , the sensor might be malfunction, ask user if he wants to raise a ticket

Q: What should I do if the soil temperature sensor is not working?
A: Check the sensor connection, tighten it if loose, and restart the device to check updated data.

Q: What should I do if the rain gauge is not working?
A: Open the top cover of the rainfall sensor and clean it as suggested in the maintenance section.

Q: Sensor is showing dry, but it rained recently.
A: Rainwater doesn't percolate well in the soil. Most of it runs off. After a day of rain stops , if the sensor is still dry, you will have to irrigate. You can check the moisture by digging near the sensor . Irrigate accordingly.

Q: What should I do if the soil moisture sensor always shows dry values?
A: Check if irrigation water is reaching the sensor, verify sensor connection, and ensure the sensor is not damaged.

messages.content:
नमस्कार अनंदा! 

तुमच्या सेन्सरने 100% पाणी दाखवले आहे, म्हणजेच माती खूपच ओलसर आहे. तुम्ही पाणी सोडल्यावर 12 तासांनी सेन्सरच्या वाचनात बदल होण्याची अपेक्षा असते. 

तुम्ही पाणी सोडल्यावर 3 दिवस झाले आहेत, तरीही सेन्सर 100% दाखवत आहे, याचा अर्थ काही समस्या असू शकते. 

कृपया खालील गोष्टी तपासा:
1. **ड्रिप सिस्टीम**: ड्रिप सिस्टीम चांगली काम करत आहे का? ड्रिप ब्लॉक झाले आहेत का?
2. **सेन्सरची स्थिती**: सेन्सरची स्थिती चांगली आहे का? सेन्सर 2 वर्षांपेक्षा जुना आहे का? 

जर तुम्हाला वाटत असेल की सेन्सरमध्ये काही समस्या आहे, तर तुम्ही तिकीट उघडू इच्छिता का?
messages.en:
Hello Ananda! 

Your sensor has shown 100% water, which means the soil is very moist. The sensor's reading is expected to change 12 hours after you release water. 

It's been 3 days since you released the water, but the sensor is still showing 100%, which could mean there may be some problems. 

Please check the following:
1. **Drip System**: Is the drip system working well? Are drips blocked?
2. **Position of the sensor**: Is the condition of the sensor good? Is the sensor more than 2 years old? 

If you think there's a problem with the sensor, would you like to open the ticket?

faq:
Q: My sensor is 200. What can be the reason ?
A: The 200 kPa means:
either the soil is fully dry or the sensor is put outside the soil or there is no current reaching the sensor rods meaning the wire is cut or connectors are removed. 
In this case, check if the moisture went to 200 kpa suddenly or it went gradually. If it went suddenly , it means the wire is broken or the connector is broken. A physical verification of the device is required in this case. Ask user to check or create a support ticket.
If it increased gradually, ask user when he irrigated last. If he has not irrigated for long time, the soil would be dry and 200 kpa is fine.

Q: My  sensor is showing 0 Kpa for long.
A: 0-5 kPa means wet soil. It can be due to following :
If the device is recently installed, there can be moisture  around the sensor because the sensor is dipped in the water before installing. If this is the case, ask them to do atleast 3 irrigations as per their previous schedule without sensors and sensors would b set by then.
If the crop stage is very early or pruing is done recently, the water takeup by plants is negligible in this period because of very less transpiration. If this is the case, ask them to wait till irrigation Kpa in the present stage.
Sometimes, the water can remain accumulated around the sensor due to local landscaping or slope in the land around sensor. In this case, please check the around the sensor. It will have to be reinstalled properly. Chatbot should ask the user if he wants to create an issue ticket for the same

messages.content:
तुमच्या "अनुष्का प्लॉट" वर सेन्सर 1 100% पाणी दाखवत आहे आणि सेन्सर 2 81% पाणी दाखवत आहे. 

सेन्सर 1 चा वाचन 100% म्हणजे माती खूपच ओलसर आहे, तर सेन्सर 2 चा वाचन 81% म्हणजे मातीमध्ये काही ओलसरपणा आहे.

तुमच्या सेन्सर 1 चा वाचन 100% असताना, तुम्ही मातीच्या खोलीत (10 इंच) ओलसरपणा तपासावा. कधी कधी, सेन्सरच्या वाचनात भिन्नता असू शकते कारण मातीच्या वरच्या स्तरावर ओलसरपणा असला तरी, खालच्या स्तरावर (20 इंच) माती अधिक कोरडी असू शकते.

कृपया मातीच्या खोलीत ओलसरपणा तपासा. जर माती खूपच कोरडी असेल, तर तुम्हाला पाणी देणे आवश्यक आहे. 

तुम्हाला आणखी काही मदतीची आवश्यकता आहे का?
messages.en:
Sensor 1 is showing 100% water on your "Anushka plot" and sensor 2 is showing 81% water. 

The reading of Sensor 1 is 100% which means that the soil is very moist, while the reading of Sensor 2 is 81% which means that there is some dampness in the soil.

When your sensor 1 reading is 100%, you should check for dampness in the soil depth (10 inches). Sometimes, the reading of the sensor can vary because while there is moisture in the upper layer of the soil, the soil at the lower level (20 inches) may be more dry.

Please check the dampness in the soil room. If the soil is too dry, you need to be watered. 

Do you need any more help?

faq:
Q: I irrigated still the sensor is showing dry.
A: Ask user when he irrigated. It usually takes 12 hours to reach the water till sensor. If the sensor is not dropping even after 12 hours, it can be due to one of the following reasons :
Water is not reaching properly till the sensor , this can be due to drip blocked , or slope in the land or dripper outlets far away from the sensor. Ask user to check if drip is fine and  dripper is within the range of sensor. 
The sensor can be very old , more than two years , in this case , the sensor might be malfunction, ask user if he wants to raise a ticket

Q: I irrigated still the sensor is dropping slowly.
A: Sometimes, the water reaches slowly till root zone and the moisture sensor kPa value drops slowly. Always wait for 12 hours after irrigation for the moisture to saturate. If still some confusion, ask user to check moisture near the sensor and check if he wants to raise a ticket for the issue.

Q: Sensor is showing dry, but it rained recently.
A: Rainwater doesn't percolate well in the soil. Most of it runs off. After a day of rain stops , if the sensor is still dry, you will have to irrigate. You can check the moisture by digging near the sensor . Irrigate accordingly.

Q: In the latest irrigation , sensor didn't drop to 0.
A: 0 to 5 Kpa means soil is fully wet. It need not drop to 0 every time. Moisture less than 5 also means wet conditions. So, need not worry. Also ask to wait for 12 hours after irrigation.

Q: My  sensor is showing 0 Kpa for long.
A: 0-5 kPa means wet soil. It can be due to following :
If the device is recently installed, there can be moisture  around the sensor because the sensor is dipped in the water before installing. If this is the case, ask them to do atleast 3 irrigations as per their previous schedule without sensors and sensors would b set by then.
If the crop stage is very early or pruing is done recently, the water takeup by plants is negligible in this period because of very less transpiration. If this is the case, ask them to wait till irrigation Kpa in the present stage.
Sometimes, the water can remain accumulated around the sensor due to local landscaping or slope in the land around sensor. In this case, please check the around the sensor. It will have to be reinstalled properly. Chatbot should ask the user if he wants to create an issue ticket for the same

messages.content: डाऊनी साठी उपाययोजना
messages.en: Measures for Downey
messages.standalone_question: What are the measures for dealing with Downy?
messages.standalone_en: What are the measures for dealing with Downy?

messages.content:
डाऊनी मळासाठी सध्या कोणतीही उपाययोजना सुचवली गेलेली नाही. तरीही, तुम्ही खालील सामान्य उपाययोजना करू शकता:

1. **साफसफाई**: प्लॉटमध्ये कोणतीही सडलेली पाने किंवा अवशेष काढा.
2. **वारा**: पिकांना चांगला वारा मिळवण्यासाठी योग्य अंतर ठेवा.
3. **पाण्याचे व्यवस्थापन**: पाण्याचे प्रमाण कमी ठेवा, कारण ओलसर वातावरण डाऊनी मळाला प्रोत्साहन देते.
4. **फफूंदनाशकांचा वापर**: योग्य फफूंदनाशकांचा वापर करा, जसे की बायोफफूंदनाशक.

तुमच्या पिकांच्या स्थितीवर लक्ष ठेवा आणि आवश्यकतेनुसार उपाययोजना करा.
messages.en:
No measures have been proposed at this time for downey mal. Still, you can take the following general measures:

1. **Cleanup**: Remove any rotten leaves or residue in the plot.
2. **Wind**: Keep a proper distance for the crops to get good wind.
3. **Water management**: Keep the amount of water low, as the moist environment promotes downy mulch.
4. **Use fungicides**: Use appropriate fungicides, such as biofluidicides.

Monitor the condition of your crops and take measures as needed.

messages.content: पिकाचेदहा मूलभूत अन्ना द्रव्य
messages.en: Ten basic nutrients of the crop
messages.standalone_question: What is the basic food of Pikachu?
messages.standalone_en: What is the basic food of Pikachu?

messages.content:
पिकांचे मूलभूत अन्न द्रव्य म्हणजेच नायट्रोजन (N), फॉस्फरस (P), आणि पोटॅशियम (K). हे तीन मुख्य अन्नद्रव्ये पिकांच्या वाढीसाठी अत्यंत आवश्यक आहेत:

1. **नायट्रोजन (N)**: पिकांच्या पानांच्या वाढीसाठी आणि सामान्यतः पिकांच्या संपूर्ण वाढीसाठी आवश्यक आहे. हे प्रथिनांच्या निर्मितीत महत्त्वाची भूमिका बजावते.

2. **फॉस्फरस (P)**: मुळांच्या विकासासाठी, फुलांच्या उत्पादनासाठी आणि फळांच्या गुणवत्तेसाठी आवश्यक आहे. हे ऊर्जा हस्तांतरणातही महत्त्वाचे आहे.

3. **पोटॅशियम (K)**: पाण्याच्या संतुलनात मदत करते, रोग प्रतिकारक क्षमता वाढवते आणि फळांच्या चवीत सुधारणा करते.

याशिवाय, कॅल्शियम, मॅग्नेशियम, आणि सल्फर यांसारखी इतर सूक्ष्म अन्नद्रव्ये देखील पिकांच्या आरोग्यासाठी आवश्यक आहेत.
messages.en:
The basic nutrients of crops are nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K). These three main nutrients are essential for the growth of crops:

1. **Nitrogen (N)**: Essential for the leaf growth of crops and for the overall growth of crops in general. It plays an important role in the formation of proteins.

2. **Phosphorus (P)***: Essential for root development, flower production, and fruit quality. It is also important in energy transfer.

3. **Potassium (K)***: Helps in water balance, boosts immunity and improves fruit taste.

In addition, other micronutrients such as calcium, magnesium, and sulfur are also essential for crop health.

messages.content: Thrips aetle shu
messages.en: Thrips aetle shu
messages.standalone_question: What is "Thrips aetle shu"?
messages.standalone_en: What is "Thrips aetle shu"?

messages.content:
Thrips (Thrips spp.) are tiny, slender insects that can cause significant damage to crops, including groundnuts. They feed on plant sap, leading to stunted growth, leaf discoloration, and reduced yield. 

**Control Measures:**
1. **Insecticides:** Use products like Imidacloprid or Thiamethoxam as per recommended dosages.
2. **Cultural Practices:** Maintain proper field hygiene, remove debris, and rotate crops to disrupt their life cycle.
3. **Biological Control:** Introduce natural predators like predatory mites or ladybugs.

Regular monitoring is essential to manage thrips effectively.

messages.content: Magafali na chod pila Kem pade che javab aapo
messages.en: Answer why peanut plants turn yellow
messages.standalone_question: Why do the leaves of groundnut plants turn yellow?
messages.standalone_en: Why do the leaves of groundnut plants turn yellow?

messages.content:
Magafali (Groundnut) na chod pila (leaves) par aavti samasyao maate kai karano hoy shake chhe:

1. **Keedano Prabhav:** Thrips, aphids, ane leaf miners jeva keedao chod na pila ne nuksan kari shake chhe. Te sap maathi khorak le chhe, je thi patta peela padva lage chhe.

2. **Rog:** Collar rot, damping off, ane seedling blight jeva rog pan chod na pila ne prabhavit kari shake chhe. 

3. **Poshak Tatvo ni Kami:** Nitrogen, phosphorus, ya potassium ni kami pan chod na pila ne peela karva maate karan banavi shake chhe.

**Niyantran Upay:**
- **Keedano Niyantran:** Chlorpyriphos @ 5mL/Ltr ya Thiamethoxam @ 0.5g/ltr na upayog thi keedao ne niyantrit karo.
- **Rog Niyantran:** Carbendazim @ 2.5g/ltr na drench/spray thi rog ne niyantrit karo.
- **Poshak Tatvo:** Soil, leaf, ya petiole testing karva thi poshak tatvo ni kami ne samjhi ne sahi fertilizer upyog karo.

Niyamit nigrani karvi khub jaruri chhe, je thi samasyao ne samay par samadhan kari shake.
messages.en:
What could be the reasons for the problems that the peanut (groundnut) plants suffer on the yellow (leaves):

1. Effect of **Insects:** Insects such as thrips, aphids, and leaf miners can damage plant yellow. He takes food from the snake, which causes the strips to turn yellow.

2. **Disease:** Diseases such as collar rot, damping off, and seedling blight can also affect plant yellowing. 

3. **Nutrient deficiencies:** Nitrogen, phosphorus, or potassium deficiency can also cause the yellowing of the plant to become pale.

**Control measures:**
* ** Control of insects:** Control insects using Chlorpirifos @ 5ml/LTR or Thiamathoxum @ 0.5G/LTR.
**Disease Control:** Control the disease with a drench/spray of carbondazim @ 2.5G/LTR.
* **Nutrients:** Use signature fertilizers to understand the nutritional deficiency by testing soil, leaf, or petiole.

It is very important to do regular nigrani so that problems can be resolved on time.

messages.content: What is weather eto
messages.en: What is weather eto
messages.standalone_question: What is the weather like in Eto?
messages.standalone_en: What is the weather like in Eto?

faq:
Q: What is ETO?
A: ETO stands for Evapotranspiration, which is the sum of evaporation and transpiration where water moves from the leaf surface and land surface to the atmosphere. The irrigation requirement and frequency are indirectly related to ETO.

messages.content: Evapotranspiration (ETO) is the process by which water is transferred from the land to the atmosphere through evaporation from soil and other surfaces, as well as transpiration from plants. It is a crucial factor in understanding water requirements for crops, as it helps determine how much water is lost to the atmosphere and how much irrigation may be needed to maintain optimal soil moisture levels for healthy plant growth.

faq:
Q: Sensor is showing wet, i.e. less kpa but soil looks dry.
A: The sensor measures the moisture around the rootzone which is not visible from the top. Ask use to check the moisture in rootzone around the sensor. If it matches, ask the user to irrigate.

Q: How to calibrate soil moisture sensors ?
A:  The way to calibrate sensors is by putting water on the sensor and it should drop. Also, there should not be any fluctuations in the soil moisture data and the pressure kpa should always be increasing. A drop after watering or irrigation and continuous dry upto 200 kpa means that the sensor is calibrated.

Q: How do I know if my soil  moisture sensor is working fine ?
A: The only way to know is if after irrigation the sensor is dropping below 5 kpa and increasing continuously unless next irrigation is done. You can try putting water on the sensor and it should drop. Also, there should not be any fluctuations in the soil moisture data and the pressure kpa should always be increasing. Also, a soil moisture reading of 0 kPa is perfectly fine, meaning wet soil, but a reading of 200 kPa could mean fault. If the soil moisture sensor reading is consistently at 0 from few 48 hours, then it could be anamolous (use live and historical hourly soil moisture data (use tool) to validate).

Q: What should I do if the soil moisture sensor values fluctuate?
A: Ensure the sensor is installed properly in the soil, check for air bubbles, and contact Fyllo representative if the issue persists.

Q: What should I do if the soil moisture sensor always shows dry values?
A: Check if irrigation water is reaching the sensor, verify sensor connection, and ensure the sensor is not damaged.

messages.content:
It's common for soil moisture sensors to show different readings due to variations in moisture levels at different depths or locations in the soil. The sensor readings reflect the moisture around the root zone, which may not always be visible from the surface.

To ensure accurate readings, you can:

1. **Check the Moisture Around the Sensors:** Dig around the sensors to see if the soil moisture matches the readings. If the soil is indeed dry around the root zone, it may be time to irrigate.

2. **Calibrate the Sensors:** If you suspect the sensors are not functioning correctly, you can calibrate them by watering the area and observing if the readings drop appropriately.

If the readings continue to differ significantly, please let me know, and I can assist you further!

messages.content:
To calibrate your soil moisture sensors, follow these steps:

1. **Water the Area:** Apply water directly to the soil around the sensor. This should cause the soil moisture reading to drop significantly.

2. **Observe the Readings:** After watering, monitor the sensor readings. The moisture level should decrease below 5 kPa, indicating that the sensor is responding correctly.

3. **Check for Consistency:** Ensure that the readings do not fluctuate significantly after watering. The pressure kPa should continuously increase as the soil dries out.

4. **Wait for Drying:** Allow the soil to dry naturally. The sensor should show increasing kPa values until it reaches around 200 kPa, indicating dry soil.

5. **Repeat if Necessary:** If the sensor does not respond as expected, repeat the watering and observation process. 

6. **Contact Support:** If issues persist, consider contacting a Fyllo representative for further assistance.

By following these steps, you can ensure that your soil moisture sensors are calibrated correctly and providing accurate readings.

messages.content: What to do for ferrous deficiency in vineyards
messages.en: What to do for ferrous deficiency in vineyards
messages.standalone_question: What steps can be taken to address ferrous deficiency in vineyards?
messages.standalone_en: What steps can be taken to address ferrous deficiency in vineyards?

messages.content:
To address ferrous (iron) deficiency in vineyards, you can take the following steps:

1. **Soil Testing:** Conduct a soil test to confirm iron deficiency and determine the pH level. High pH can inhibit iron availability.

2. **Foliar Application:** Apply iron chelates (like Fe-EDTA or Fe-DTPA) as a foliar spray. This method allows for quick absorption by the leaves.

3. **Soil Amendments:** If soil pH is high, consider applying sulfur or organic matter to lower the pH, which can improve iron availability.

4. **Fertigation:** If you have a fertigation system, you can inject iron chelates into the irrigation water for better distribution.

5. **Monitor Plant Health:** Keep an eye on the symptoms of iron deficiency, such as interveinal chlorosis (yellowing between the veins of young leaves), and adjust your treatment accordingly.

6. **Regular Maintenance:** Ensure proper drainage and avoid overwatering, as waterlogged conditions can exacerbate iron deficiency.

7. **Consult an Agronomist:** If the deficiency persists, consider consulting an agronomist for tailored recommendations based on your specific vineyard conditions.

By following these steps, you can effectively manage ferrous deficiency in your vineyards and promote healthy growth.

messages.content: Calcium
messages.en: Calcium
messages.standalone_question: What should be done to address calcium deficiency in vineyards?
messages.standalone_en: What should be done to address calcium deficiency in vineyards?

messages.content:
Calcium deficiency in vineyards can lead to various issues, including poor fruit development and blossom end rot. Here are steps to address calcium deficiency:

1. **Soil Testing:** Conduct a soil test to confirm calcium levels and pH. This will help you understand the soil's nutrient status.

2. **Calcium Amendments:** Apply calcium sources such as:
   - **Calcium carbonate (lime):** Useful for raising pH and adding calcium.
   - **Gypsum (calcium sulfate):** Good for adding calcium without affecting pH.
   - **Calcium nitrate:** Provides both calcium and nitrogen.

3. **Foliar Application:** Use calcium sprays (like calcium chloride or calcium nitrate) on the leaves for quick absorption, especially during critical growth stages.

4. **Irrigation Management:** Ensure proper irrigation practices to avoid water stress, which can exacerbate calcium deficiency.

5. **Organic Matter:** Incorporate organic matter (like compost) into the soil to improve nutrient availability and soil structure.

6. **Monitor Symptoms:** Keep an eye on symptoms such as blossom end rot, poor fruit set, and leaf curling, and adjust your treatment accordingly.

7. **Consult an Agronomist:** If the deficiency persists, consider consulting an agronomist for tailored recommendations based on your specific vineyard conditions.

By following these steps, you can effectively manage calcium deficiency in your vineyards and promote healthy growth.

messages.content: How to lower magnesium in water
messages.en: How to lower magnesium in water
messages.standalone_question: What methods can be used to lower magnesium levels in water?
messages.standalone_en: What methods can be used to lower magnesium levels in water?

messages.content:
To lower magnesium levels in water for your vineyard, you can consider the following methods:

1. **Water Source Management:** If possible, switch to a water source with lower magnesium content. Test different water sources to find one that meets your needs.

2. **Reverse Osmosis (RO) Filtration:** Use RO systems to filter out excess magnesium and other minerals from the water. This method is effective but may require investment in equipment.

3. **Chemical Treatment:** You can use chemical agents like calcium sulfate (gypsum) to precipitate magnesium from the water. This method may require careful monitoring and adjustment.

4. **Dilution:** If you have access to water with lower magnesium levels, you can dilute the high-magnesium water with it to achieve a more balanced concentration.

5. **Regular Monitoring:** Continuously monitor magnesium levels in your water supply to ensure they remain within acceptable limits for your crops.

6. **Consult an Agronomist:** If magnesium levels are consistently high, consider consulting an agronomist for tailored recommendations based on your specific situation.

By implementing these methods, you can effectively manage and lower magnesium levels in your water supply for your vineyard.

messages.content: What's the effect on plants
messages.en: What's the effect on plants
messages.standalone_question: What are the effects of high magnesium levels on plants?
messages.standalone_en: What are the effects of high magnesium levels on plants?

messages.content:
The effects of magnesium deficiency on plants, particularly in vineyards, can include:

1. **Chlorosis:** Yellowing of leaves, especially between the veins, as magnesium is essential for chlorophyll production.

2. **Poor Fruit Development:** Insufficient magnesium can lead to reduced fruit size and quality, affecting overall yield.

3. **Leaf Curling:** Leaves may curl or become distorted, impacting photosynthesis and plant health.

4. **Interveinal Chlorosis:** This specific type of yellowing occurs between the leaf veins, indicating a lack of magnesium.

5. **Reduced Photosynthesis:** Magnesium is crucial for photosynthesis, and its deficiency can hinder the plant's ability to produce energy.

6. **Increased Susceptibility to Disease:** Weakened plants may become more vulnerable to pests and diseases.

7. **Stunted Growth:** Overall growth may be stunted, leading to smaller plants and reduced vigor.

Addressing magnesium deficiency promptly is essential to maintain healthy plant growth and maximize yield in your vineyard.

messages.content: High magnesium in plants what will affect
messages.en: High magnesium in plants what will affect
messages.standalone_question: What are the effects of high magnesium levels in plants?
messages.standalone_en: What are the effects of high magnesium levels in plants?

messages.content:
High magnesium levels in plants can lead to several negative effects, including:

1. **Nutrient Imbalance:** Excess magnesium can interfere with the uptake of other essential nutrients, particularly calcium and potassium, leading to deficiencies in those nutrients.

2. **Leaf Symptoms:** High magnesium levels may cause leaf chlorosis (yellowing) and necrosis (death of tissue), particularly in older leaves.

3. **Reduced Photosynthesis:** An imbalance in nutrient levels can hinder the plant's ability to photosynthesize effectively, impacting growth and yield.

4. **Poor Fruit Quality:** Excess magnesium can lead to poor fruit development, affecting size, taste, and overall quality.

5. **Increased Susceptibility to Disease:** Plants with nutrient imbalances may become more vulnerable to pests and diseases.

6. **Stunted Growth:** Overall plant growth may be stunted, leading to smaller plants and reduced vigor.

7. **Soil Health Issues:** High magnesium levels can alter soil structure and affect microbial activity, leading to long-term soil health issues.

Managing magnesium levels is crucial for maintaining plant health and optimizing crop yield. If you suspect high magnesium levels, consider soil testing and consulting with an agronomist for tailored recommendations.

messages.content:
आपल्या "Plot no 1" मध्ये सध्या "Growth stage 1" आहे, आणि या आठवड्यात (आठवडा 4) कोणतीही खताची गरज नाही. 

पण पुढील आठवड्यात (आठवडा 5) खालील खतांचा वापर करावा लागेल:

1. **Potassium Nitrate** - 1 kg/acre
2. **Urea** - 1 kg/acre
3. **Calcium Nitrate** - 1.5 kg/acre (याला इतर खतांच्या अनुप्रयोगानंतर 15-20 मिनिटांनी लागू करावे)

कृपया लक्षात ठेवा की पुढील खताची तारीख 7 ऑगस्ट 2025 आहे.

But the following fertilizers will have to be used next week (week 5):

1. **Potassium Nitrate** - 1 kg/acre
2. **Urea** - 1 kg/acre
3. **Calcium Nitrate** - 1.5 kg/acre (apply it 15-20 minutes after application of other fertilizers)

Please note that the next fertilizer date is August 7, 2025.

faq:
Q: Do I need to do fertigation on my farm?
A: Fyllo provides a fixed fertigation schedule based on plot and crop details, along with weather forecasting data for farmer plots, to decide the fertilizer/fertigation needs.

Q: What are mixed fertilizers (NPK)?
A: NPK fertilizers are represented by a three-number sequence, such as 10-10-10, indicating the percentage by weight of each nutrient. For example, 10-10-10 means the fertilizer contains 10% Nitrogen, 10% Phosphorus, and 10% Potassium elements in the chemical mixture. Some examples are below:
0-40-37, 0-40-40, 0-49-32, 0-52-34 (Mono potassium phosphate), 0-55-18, 0-60-20, 0-9-46, 10-26-26, 10-54-10, 11-44-11, 12-11-18, 12-32-16, 12-61-0, 13-0-45 (Potassium Nitrate), 13-40-13, 19-19-19, 20-20-0-13 (Ammonium Phosphate Sulphate), 24-24-0, 30-10-10, 6-34-17
Or 0:40:37, 0:40:40, 0:49:32, 0:52:34 (Mono potassium phosphate), 0:55:18, 0:60:20, 0:9:46, 10:26:26, 10:54:10, 11:44:11, 12:11:18, 12:32:16, 12:61:0, 13:0:45 (Potassium Nitrate), 13:40:13, 19:19:19, 20:20:0:13 (Ammonium Phosphate Sulphate), 24:24:0, 30:10:10, 6:34:17
Or 0.40.37, 0.40.40, 0.49.32, 0.52.34 (Mono potassium phosphate), 0.55.18, 0.60.20, 0.9.46, 10.26.26, 10.54.10, 11.44.11, 12.11.18, 12.32.16, 12.61.0, 13.0.45 (Potassium Nitrate), 13.40.13, 19.19.19, 20.20.0.13 (Ammonium Phosphate Sulphate), 24.24.0, 30.10.10, 6.34.17

તમારા ખેતરમાં (Muskmelon) માટેની ખાતરની જરૂરિયાતો નીચે મુજબ છે:

### **Main Palot 971 (4 acres)**
**વર્તમાન તબક્કો:** Flowering and Fruiting (સપ્તાહ 1)
- **ફોલિયર પદ્ધતિ દ્વારા:** 
  - **Solubor:** 500 gm/acre (1% Concentration)
  
- **ફર્ટિગેશન પદ્ધતિ દ્વારા:**
  - **Day 1:**
    - **Potassium Nitrate:** 1 kg/acre
    - **Urea:** 2.5 kg/acre
  - **Day 4:**
    - **12-61-0:** 2 kg/acre
    - **Urea:** 2.5 kg/acre
    - **Calcium nitrate:** 3 kg/acre

### **Palot 812 (2.5 acres)**
**વર્તમાન તબક્કો:** Flowering and Fruiting (સપ્તાહ 2)
- **ફોલિયર પદ્ધતિ દ્વારા:**
  - **Manganese Sulphate:** 400 gm/acre
  - **Zinc Sulphate:** 600 gm/acre
  - **Ferrous Sulphate:** 500 gm/acre

- **ફર્ટિગેશન પદ્ધતિ દ્વારા:**
  - **Day 1:**
    - **Potassium Nitrate:** 3 kg/acre
    - **Magnesium Sulphate:** 3 kg/acre
  - **Day 4:**
    - **Calcium nitrate:** 3 kg/acre
    - **Sulfate of Potash:** 3 kg/acre

### **આગામી તબક્કો:**
- **Fruit maturity** (સપ્તાહ 1) માટેની ખાતર જરૂરિયાતો પણ ઉપલબ્ધ છે.

આ માહિતી અનુસાર, ખાતરનો ઉપયોગ કરો અને ખાતરી કરો કે તમે યોગ્ય પદ્ધતિઓનો ઉપયોગ કરી રહ્યા છો.
messages.en:
The fertilizer requirements for your farm (Muskmelon) are as follows:

### **Main Palot 971 (4 acres)**
**Current Phase:** Flowering and Fruiting (Week 1)
* **By foliar method:** 
  - **Solubor:** 500 gm/acre (1% Concentration)
  
- **By fertigation method:**
  - **Day 1:**
    - **Potassium Nitrate:** 1 kg/acre
    - **Urea:** 2.5 kg/acre
  - **Day 4:**
    - **12-61-0:** 2 kg/acre
    - **Urea:** 2.5 kg/acre
    - **Calcium nitrate:** 3 kg/acre

### **Palot 812 (2.5 acres)**
**Current Phase:** Flowering and Fruiting (Week 2)
* **By foliar method:**
  - **Manganese Sulphate:** 400 gm/acre
  - **Zinc Sulphate:** 600 gm/acre
  - **Ferrous Sulphate:** 500 gm/acre

- **By fertigation method:**
  - **Day 1:**
    - **Potassium Nitrate:** 3 kg/acre
    - **Magnesium Sulphate:** 3 kg/acre
  - **Day 4:**
    - **Calcium nitrate:** 3 kg/acre
    - **Sulfate of Potash:** 3 kg/acre

### **Next stage:**
Fertilizer requirements for **Fruit maturity** (Week 1) are also available.

According to this information, use fertilizer and make sure you are using the right methods.

faq:
Q: Do I need to do fertigation on my farm?
A: Fyllo provides a fixed fertigation schedule based on plot and crop details, along with weather forecasting data for farmer plots, to decide the fertilizer/fertigation needs.

Q: What are mixed fertilizers (NPK)?
A: NPK fertilizers are represented by a three-number sequence, such as 10-10-10, indicating the percentage by weight of each nutrient. For example, 10-10-10 means the fertilizer contains 10% Nitrogen, 10% Phosphorus, and 10% Potassium elements in the chemical mixture. Some examples are below:
0-40-37, 0-40-40, 0-49-32, 0-52-34 (Mono potassium phosphate), 0-55-18, 0-60-20, 0-9-46, 10-26-26, 10-54-10, 11-44-11, 12-11-18, 12-32-16, 12-61-0, 13-0-45 (Potassium Nitrate), 13-40-13, 19-19-19, 20-20-0-13 (Ammonium Phosphate Sulphate), 24-24-0, 30-10-10, 6-34-17
Or 0:40:37, 0:40:40, 0:49:32, 0:52:34 (Mono potassium phosphate), 0:55:18, 0:60:20, 0:9:46, 10:26:26, 10:54:10, 11:44:11, 12:11:18, 12:32:16, 12:61:0, 13:0:45 (Potassium Nitrate), 13:40:13, 19:19:19, 20:20:0:13 (Ammonium Phosphate Sulphate), 24:24:0, 30:10:10, 6:34:17
Or 0.40.37, 0.40.40, 0.49.32, 0.52.34 (Mono potassium phosphate), 0.55.18, 0.60.20, 0.9.46, 10.26.26, 10.54.10, 11.44.11, 12.11.18, 12.32.16, 12.61.0, 13.0.45 (Potassium Nitrate), 13.40.13, 19.19.19, 20.20.0.13 (Ammonium Phosphate Sulphate), 24.24.0, 30.10.10, 6.34.17

messages.content: Tomato viruses
messages.en: Tomato viruses
messages.standalone_question: What are the common viruses that affect tomatoes?
messages.standalone_en: What are the common viruses that affect tomatoes?

messages.content:
Fyllo supports the following diseases that can affect tomatoes:

1. **Alternaria** - Causes leaf spots and blight.
2. **Anthracnose** - Leads to dark, sunken lesions on fruits.
3. **Bacterial Blight** - Results in water-soaked spots on leaves.
4. **Cercospora** - Causes leaf spot diseases.
5. **Fusarium Wilt** - Affects the vascular system, leading to wilting.
6. **Powdery Mildew** - Characterized by white powdery spots on leaves.
7. **Tomato Mosaic Virus** - Causes mottled leaves and stunted growth.

If you need specific information or predictions regarding any of these diseases, please let me know!

messages.content: Chealated micro nutrients vise janavso
messages.en: Chealated micro nutrients vise janavso
messages.standalone_question: What are chelated micronutrients?
messages.standalone_en: What are chelated micronutrients?

messages.content:
Chealated micro nutrients are essential for the healthy growth of crops like muskmelon. Here are some commonly used chelated micro nutrients:

1. **Iron (Fe)**: Important for chlorophyll synthesis and overall plant health.
2. **Zinc (Zn)**: Crucial for enzyme function and growth regulation.
3. **Manganese (Mn)**: Plays a role in photosynthesis and nitrogen metabolism.
4. **Copper (Cu)**: Necessary for photosynthesis and respiration.
5. **Boron (B)**: Important for cell wall formation and reproductive growth.
6. **Molybdenum (Mo)**: Essential for nitrogen fixation and enzyme activity.

Using chelated forms of these nutrients ensures better absorption by plants, especially in alkaline soils where nutrients may become less available. It's advisable to conduct soil tests to determine the specific needs of your crop and apply these nutrients accordingly.

messages.content:
માઇક્રો નૂટ્રીઅન્ટના કોમ્બિનેશન માટે નીચેના તત્વોનો સમાવેશ કરી શકાય છે:

1. **આયરન (Fe)**: 0.1% - 0.5%
2. **ઝિંક (Zn)**: 0.1% - 0.5%
3. **મૅંગેનીઝ (Mn)**: 0.1% - 0.5%
4. **કોપર (Cu)**: 0.05% - 0.2%
5. **બોરોન (B)**: 0.1% - 0.3%
6. **મોલિબ્ડેનમ (Mo)**: 0.01% - 0.1%

આ કોમ્બિનેશનનો ઉપયોગ કરીને, તમે તમારા પાકની જરૂરિયાતો અનુસાર માઇક્રો નૂટ્રીઅન્ટ્સ પૂરા કરી શકો છો. આ તત્વોનું યોગ્ય પ્રમાણ પાકની વૃદ્ધિ અને વિકાસ માટે મહત્વપૂર્ણ છે. ખાતરનો ઉપયોગ કરતા પહેલા, જમીન અને પાંદડાના પરીક્ષણો કરવું શ્રેષ્ઠ રહેશે, જેથી ચોક્કસ જરૂરિયાતો જાણી શકાય.
messages.en:
The following elements can be included for the combination of micronutrients:

1. **Iron (Fe)**: 0.1% - 0.5%
2. **Zinc (Zn)**: 0.1% - 0.5%
3. **Manganese (Mn)**: 0.1% - 0.5%
4. **Copper (Cu)**: 0.05% - 0.2%
5. **Boron (B)**: 0.1% - 0.3%
6. **Molybdenum (Mo)**: 0.01% - 0.1%

Using this combination, you can complete micronutrients according to the needs of your crop. The right amount of these elements is important for the growth and development of the crop. Before using fertilizer, it would be best to do soil and leaf tests, so that the exact needs can be known.

Q: which are the insecticide and fungicide to be used for seed treatment
A: Insecticide:  Imidacloprid 600 FS – 5 to 8 ml/kg seeds
Fungicide: Thiram – 2 to 3 gm/kg seed

Q: Can fungicide and insecticide be sprayed together?
A: For fungicides and insecticides to be sprayed together, it is important to consider factors like compatibility. For expert guidance tailored to your situation, we recommend reaching out to Fyllo’s CRM number for personalized advice.

faq:
Q: Which crop or variety is best suited for farming? Which variety is more profitable, gives the highest yield, or offers better resistance to pests and diseases? Best crops/varieties in my village/locality area. Best crop/crop variety in state.
A: The best crop variety depends on multiple factors like soil type, climate, pest resistance, and market demand. However, selecting the **right variety for your specific farm requires expert consultation.** Farming success depends on local conditions, so it’s best to get personalized advice. For precise recommendations, please contact the expert agronomy team. Please consult our CRM team for more Agronomy related information.

Q: Do I need to spray?
A: Check the disease pest spray schedule for the farmer and reply accordingly. Don't check metrics, only pre-defined schedules to be checked.

Q: What are the important diseases occur during seedling stage and control measures?
A: Collar rot, Damping off, Seedling blight diseases infect during seedling stage.
Drench/spray seedling with: Carbendazim @ 2.5g/ltr

Q: How to improve the germination percent
A: Use of good quality seeds and seeds to be treated with insecticide, Fungicide and biological agents

Q: why to use insecticide and fungicide for seed treatment?
A:
- Prevents the spread of plant diseases/pest
- Protects the seed from seed rot and seedling blights
- Improves the seed germination
- Provides protection from storage insects
- Controls the soil insects

messages.content:
It seems that there are no specific spray suggestions available for pomegranate at the fruiting stage based on the image analysis. However, here are some general recommendations for managing pests and diseases in pomegranates:

1. **Inspect for Pests**: Check for signs of fruit flies or other pests that may be causing damage.
2. **Sanitation**: Remove any affected fruits and debris from the area to prevent the spread of disease.
3. **Fungicides**: Consider using a broad-spectrum fungicide if fungal infections are suspected.

For more targeted treatment, I recommend consulting with a local agricultural expert or extension service who can provide specific products suitable for your region and situation. If you have a clearer image of the affected area, it may help in providing a more accurate assessment.

The analysis of the uploaded image indicates that there are no specific spray suggestions available for pomegranate at the fruiting stage. However, here are some general practices to manage potential issues:

1. **Inspect for Pests**: Look for any visible pests on the fruit or leaves.
2. **Remove Affected Fruits**: If you notice significant damage, consider removing the affected fruits to prevent the spread of disease.
3. **Maintain Hygiene**: Keep the area around the plants clean and free from fallen fruits or debris that can harbor pests.
4. **Fungicide Application**: If you suspect fungal issues, applying a general fungicide may be beneficial.

For more tailored advice and potential treatments, it's advisable to consult with a local agricultural expert or extension service.
